stem: A client is 5 days post-anterior myocardial infarction (MI) with a large area of left ventricular wall motion abnormality (hypokinesis). Based on the documentation in the Post-MI Thrombotic & Perfusion Log, which finding indicates the most likely complication?

options.text: Embolic stroke from a ventricular mural thrombus

rationale.correct: The most likely complication is an **embolic stroke (a1)** originating from a **mural thrombus**. After a large MI, the heart muscle may exhibit akinesis or hypokinesis, leading to stagnant blood in the left ventricle that can clot against the wall, forming a mural thrombus. If a piece of this clot breaks off, it can travel to the brain (a1) or the limbs. The echocardiogram finding of a left ventricular thrombus, combined with the sudden facial droop and aphasia, is highly suggestive of an embolic event.
clinicalPearls: Mural thrombus refers to a clot on the wall of the heart.
Patients with left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) less than 30% or large anterior MIs often require anticoagulation (e.g., warfarin) for 3-6 months to prevent mural thrombus formation.
Priority actions include a stat CT head scan and neurology consultation.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting hemorrhagic stroke (a2) because the patient is receiving blood thinners.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While possible, the known presence of a left ventricular mural thrombus on the echocardiogram report makes an embolic (clot) cause significantly more likely. Prioritize clinical reasoning based on known anatomical risks.

mnemonic.title: Wall to Brain
mnemonic.expansion: Stagnant heart. Mural start. Breaks apart. Stroke at the chart.

exhibits.title: Clinical Status History
exhibits.content:
Post-Op Day 1-4: Stable heart rate (70s), sinus rhythm. Client ambulating in room.
Day 5 (0800): Sudden onset of right-sided facial droop and right-arm weakness. Aphasia (inability to speak) noted.

exhibits.title: Echocardiogram (admission)
exhibits.content: LVEF: 25%. Finding: Large akinesis of the apex. Presence of a **mural thrombus** (clot attached to the heart wall) noted in the left ventricle.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & Neuro (0815)
exhibits.content: BP 168/94 mmHg, HR 82 bpm, SpO2 96%. NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) Score: 18 (Severe).
